bioghist.p: West Mt. Airy Neighbors is a Pennsylvania non-profit organization that was founded in 1959 to create and sustain West Mt. Airy as a racially integrated community. It was founded by George Schermer, the first Director of Philadelphiaâ€™s Human Relations Commission, and other neighbors concerned about white flight and block busting. Committees of the Associaton work on issues of concern to the community, including planning, city services, community relations, and housing. The current boundaries of the organization's service area are Fairmount Park on the West, Cresheim Valley Road on the North, Johnson Street on the South, and Germantown Avenue of the East.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes records of West Mount Airy Neighbors from the offices of David T. Moore, Administrator, Laurie Beck Tarver, Executive Director, Nancy A. Goldenberg, Executive Director, and Marilyn Shane, President. Records document administrative, personnel and financial matters, the board of directors, event planning, and the work of various committees, including Executive, Advisory, Membership, Arts & Culture, Zoning, Schools, and Beautification. The Association's work on fundraising, publicity and development, volunteering, community organizations, zoning, safety, beautification, housing, and roads is documented through minutes, agendas, memoranda, notes, reports, and clippings. A number of printed materials are present, including flyers, announcements, posters, newsletters, and West Mount Airy community and business directories. The collection also contains records related to various events, including Mount Airy Day planning materials, 1983-2002, and materials related to the Pelham Anniversary Celebration, 1992-1993. There are subject files on a variety of topics, people, city offices and programs, and other community organizations. The collection also contains several studies and reports, most notably a 1989 survey of neighbors and East Mount Airy Neighbors/West Mount Airy Neighbors joint committee reports.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
